xml_context:
Signatures appear less frequently toward the end of his Middle Period and cease altogether in the Late Period. Douris' stylistic development is also linked with different kalos names: Chairestratos and Panaitios, which occur early, and Hippodamas, a favorite in the Middle Period. Besides helping establish an internal chronology, two of these names have been connected with historical figures: Panaitios, who took part in the Persian wars (Hdt. 8.82); and Hippodamas, who was strategos in 459/8. A third name, Hermolykos, appears on a cup in the Getty Museum (Malibu 83.AE.217;

; ; ; ) and Herodotus mentions a man of this name who distinguished himself in the Persian wars at the battle of Mykale in 479 B.C. ().

Malibu 83.AE.217; ; ; ; ) and Herodotus mentions a man of this name who distinguished himself in the Persian wars at the battle of Mykale in 479 B.C. (Hdt. 9.105).

Hippodamas: IG I 433, 63; Hermolykos: .

 Finally, Athenodotos is written on a cup in Athens where the name of Douris, perhaps the vase-painter Douris is invoked (Athens 1666, ). Athenodotos is named as kalos on two vases that also praise Leagros (Boston 10.179; ; ; London 97.10-28.1; ).

The exterior shows fight scenes. On side A, Menelaos chases Paris, whose mouth is open as he gasps for breath; Hera and Artemis are in the wings. On side B, Athena and Apollo flank Ajax, who, armed with shield and spear, has hurled a rock at Hector, a method of combat he resorted to several times according to Homer (Hom. Il. 7.268-272; ).

A cup in Malibu (Malibu 84.AE.569;

; ; ; ) and the cup with Eos and Memnon share the tongue pattern forming the line of the tondo exergue. The figure style shows many similarities as well. In the Malibu tondo, a bearded man, perhaps Zeus, sits on a stool before an elaborate altar with a snake pediment and palmette acroterion. He holds a kylix straight out in front of him, a little too close to the youth, Ganymede, who has had to contract his own arm and holds his oinochoe awkwardly in order to pour into the cup. Zeus displays an eager impetuosity before which Ganymede retreats slightly, a subtlety of emotion effectively conveyed by Douris.

On side B, Athena and Apollo flank Ajax, who, armed with shield and spear, has hurled a rock at Hector, a method of combat he resorted to several times according to Homer (Hom. Il. 7.268-272; Hom. Il. 14.409-415).

A cup in Malibu (Malibu 84.AE.569;

In the Malibu tondo, a bearded man, perhaps Zeus, sits on a stool before an elaborate altar with a snake pediment and palmette acroterion. He holds a kylix straight out in front of him, a little too close to the youth, Ganymede, who has had to contract his own arm and holds his oinochoe awkwardly in order to pour into the cup. Zeus displays an eager impetuosity before which Ganymede retreats slightly, a subtlety of emotion effectively conveyed by Douris.

. The Prytanes, having charge of the conduct of business in the Ecclesia, are said protiqe/nai gnw/mas, lo/gon, yh=fon, to bring forward a subject for discussion or voting. The imperfect implies that their action is regarded as continuing throughout the debate. Cf. Isocr. de Pace 15 parelh/luqa a)pofanou/menos...peri\ w(=n oi( pruta/neis protiqe/asin. For the infinitive replacing the more usual accusative cf. Thuc. III.38 tw=n proqe/ntwn au)=qis peri\ *mutilhnai/wn le/gein.

tw=n ei)wqo/twn, sc. gnw/mhn a)pofai/nesqai.

a)pefh/nanto. The middle is regularly used with gnw/mhn in this sense. The constructions following e(/ws (except in clauses referring to a definite event in past time) are identical with the constructions of conditional clauses. Hence the past indicative here in dependence on a conditional sentence of an unfulfilled character.

pratto/ntwn. The subject of a participle used absolutely in the genitive is sometimes omitted when (1) it can be supplied easily from the context, or (2) it is indefinite.

gene/sqai refers of course to time which, in relation to e)lpi\s h)=n, is future. But after verbs and verbal phrases expressing hope the aorist infinitive is sometimes so employed. Cf. Thuc. IV.24 to\ *(rh/gion h)/lpizon r(a|di/ws xeirw/sasqai. Indeed the aorist, except in the indicative and in the infinitive and participle where these in some sense represent indicatives, carries no significance of time. a)\n must of course be taken with h)=n.

a)kou/ousi and

a)namimnh|skome/nois are syntactically parallel: the former participle seems at first to agree with u(mi=n understood, but the subdivision of u(mi=n which appears in the second member with toi=s ei)do/sin au)toi=s makes it clear that a)kou/ousi is intended to apply only to toi=s mh\ au)toi=s ei)do/sin u(mw=n. Cf. Thuc. I.42 w(=n e)nqumhqe/ntes kai\ new/tero/s tis para\ presbute/rwn au)ta\ maqw/n.

au)toi=s, almost by personal experience, with ei)do/sin.

h(li/khn ... w(s kalw=s . The double question, whether direct or reported, is a regular Greek idiom. Cf. h( ti/si ti/ a)podidou=sa te/xnh; . In instances like the present there is some doubt whether forms like

toi=s mh\ au)toi=s ei)do/sin u(mw=n. Cf. Thuc. I.42 w(=n e)nqumhqe/ntes kai\ new/tero/s tis para\ presbute/rwn au)ta\ maqw/n.

au)toi=s, almost by personal experience, with ei)do/sin.

h(li/khn ... w(s kalw=s . The double question, whether direct or reported, is a regular Greek idiom. Cf. Plato, Rep. 332 D h( ti/si ti/ a)podidou=sa te/xnh; . In instances like the present there is some doubt whether forms like h(li/kos and oi(=os are to be regarded (1) as used loosely for the dependent interrogative forms (o(phli/kos, o(poi=os, &c.), (2) as dependent exclamations, or (3) as strictly relative.

In instances like the present there is some doubt whether forms like h(li/kos and oi(=os are to be regarded (1) as used loosely for the dependent interrogative forms (o(phli/kos, o(poi=os, &c.), (2) as dependent exclamations, or (3) as strictly relative.

circumstances only those between 20 and 50 were called out for foreign service, and commonly only in part.

sunelo/nti, apparently a dative due to ellipse. Cf. Isaeus 4. 22 sunelo/nti polu\ to\ dia/feron.

In Xenophon we have a fuller phrase w(s sunelo/nti ei)pei=n (e.g. An. 3. 1. 38) in which it is easy to supply e)sti/as one summing up the matter may say. aplw=s, if retained, is to be taken with gene/sqai u(mw=n au)tw=n; some commentators would omit it.

u(mw=n au)tw=n, your own men: we should look at the matter from the other side and say your own masters.

au)to\s me\n k.t.e(. Take au)to\s

kata\ cf. katakubeu/ein to gamble away, katafronti/zein to lose by taking thought.

a)qa/nata, predicatively with pephge/nai.

misei= tis. The singular tis is here used in a sort of collective sense, many a one. Similarly Thuc. III.111 kai/ tinas au)tw=n tw=n strathgw=n h)ko/ntise tis. Not infrequently tis is used with active verbs, like on in French, in substitution for a passive construction.

pa/nu, with oi)kei/ws rather than with dokou/ntwn.

a(/panta, all the characteristics, feelings or impulses.

pa/nu, with oi)kei/ws rather than with dokou/ntwn.

a(/panta, all the characteristics, feelings or impulses.

a)postrofh/n , o(/poi a)postrafw=si, rallying-centreapparently a metaphor from tactics. The alternative rendering refuge does not suit the general sense so well. Cf. Thuc. IV.76 ou)/shs e(ka/stois dia\ braxe/os a)postrofh=s.

h)/dh, placed at the end for emphasis.

o(ra=te, indicative or imperative?

oi(=, with a)selgei/as, to what lengths of outrage. Cf. . So e)ntau=q' a)fiko/mhn kakou=Cho.

Thuc. IV.76 ou)/shs e(ka/stois dia\ braxe/os a)postrofh=s.

h)/dh, placed at the end for emphasis.

o(ra=te, indicative or imperative?

oi(=, with a)selgei/as, to what lengths of outrage. Cf. Soph. El. 1035 oi(= m' a)timi/as a)/geis. So e)ntau=q' a)fiko/mhn kakou=Cho. 691, but the demonstrative form is generally ei)s tou=to or tosou=to: cf. Dem. 18. 22 ei)s tou=q' h(=ken a)naidei/as. The clause introduced by oi(= is epexegetic of to\ pra=gma.

be/ltion, sc. h(mw=n e)pimelei=tai. When a verb serves as predicate to more than one subject, it frequently agrees with the nearest subject only. This occurs sometimes even when the subjects are, as here, not co-ordinate; cf. Thuc. 1. 82 o(/soi w(/sper kai\ h(mei=s u(p' *)aqhnai/wn e)pibouleuo/meqa (sc. e)pibouleu/ontai). For the thought, cf. Aristoph. Clouds 587 sqq., and compare the modern Briton's pride in muddling through difficulties in public affairs.

o)/ntes, equivalent to ei) ei)/hte, antithetic, verbally to w(s nu=n e)/xete, and in sense to a)phrthme/noi.

e)pista/ntes, as well as

e)gnwke/nai o(/ti pleuste/on e)sti/n. Do not however take w(s as equivalent to o(/ti and supply e)sti/: the ou(/tw shews that w(s is to be taken as its correlative, and with pleuste/on we must supply o)/n (acc. absol.). The phrase is of a fairly common type; cf. Thuc. VII.15 w(s kai\ tw=n stratiwtw=n kai\ tw=n h(gemo/nwn mh\ memptw=n gegenhme/nwn, ou(/tw th\n gnw/mhn e)/xete, w(s toi/nun mh\ a)kousome/nwn ou(/tws dianoei=sqe.

toi=s h(mi/sesi, assimilated in gender and number to the substantive which depends on it: cf. o( h(/misus tou= xro/nou (Dem. 20. 8), ai( h(mi/seiai tw=n new=n

VII.15 w(s kai\ tw=n stratiwtw=n kai\ tw=n h(gemo/nwn mh\ memptw=n gegenhme/nwn, ou(/tw th\n gnw/mhn e)/xete, Plato, Rep. 327 C w(s toi/nun mh\ a)kousome/nwn ou(/tws dianoei=sqe.

toi=s h(mi/sesi, assimilated in gender and number to the substantive which depends on it: cf. o( h(/misus tou= xro/nou (Dem. 20. 8), ai( h(mi/seiai tw=n new=n (): also the neuter is used as in to\ h(/misu tou= stra/tou.

paridw/n, overlooking, looking past, instead of at a thing, somewhat like periidei=n.

mhdeno/s, neuter; not ou)deno/s, because of the dependence on i(/na and the conditional character of the whole sentence.

a)\n e)ndw=| kairo/n, if he offers us a chance; so Aristoph. Knights 847 labh\n ga\r e)nde/dwkas. The inferior MSS. give kairo/s

19-22 Before we prepare the force I have mentioned, we must establish an offensive force to maintain the war continuously. It must not be a mere paper army of mercenaries, but must contain citizens (19). I will go into detail. Only do not make your usual mistake of passing decrees on a vast scale and leaving them wholly inoperative: better to make small plans and carry them out (20). I suggest a force of 2000 footmen and 200 horse, of whom a quarter must be citizens (21); also ten ships of war. I will explain why that will suffice (22).

boh/qeiai) for a particular purpose and allow them to return on the completion of the immediate operations.

mh/ moi, supply a transitive imperative (e.g. ei)/phte or ei)pa/tw tis) to govern the accusative; cf. Aristoph. Ach. 345 mh/ moi pro/fasin

e)pistolimai/ous

th=s po/lews e)/stai, shall really belong to the city in contrast with the armies of mercenaries, which easily got out of control and sought their own profit more readily than that of their employers: see 24.

ka)\n u(mei=s. The is needed both as a copula to connect pei/setai
